   clojure.contrib.seq-utils/seq-on and
   clojure.contrib.generic.collection/seq for streams.

vars.name: stream-type
vars.doc:
The root type for the stream hierarchy. For each stream type,
   add a derivation from this type.

vars.name: apply-template
vars.doc:
Replaces _1, _2, _3, etc. in expr with corresponding elements of
  values.  Returns the modified expression.  For use in macros.

vars.name: do-template
vars.doc:
Repeatedly evaluates template expr (in a do block) using values in
  args.  args are grouped by the number of holes in the template.
  Example: (do-template (check _1 _2) :a :b :c :d)
  expands to (do (check :a :b) (check :c :d))

vars.name: find-holes
vars.doc: Recursively finds all symbols starting with _ in form.

vars.name: find-pure-exprs
vars.doc:
Recursively finds all sub-expressions in form that do not contain
  any symbols starting with _

vars.name: find-symbols
vars.doc: Recursively finds all symbols in form.

vars.name: flatten-map
vars.doc: Transforms a map into a vector like [key value key value].

vars.name: template
vars.doc:
Expands to a fn using _1, _2, _3, etc. as arguments (_ is the same
  as _1).  Any sub-expressions without any _* variables are evaluated
  when the fn is created, not when it is called.

vars.name: template?
vars.doc: Returns true if form is a valid template expression.

vars.name: *load-tests*
vars.doc:
True by default.  If set to false, no test functions will
   be created by deftest, set-test, or with-test.  Use this to omit
   tests when compiling or loading production code.

vars.name: *stack-trace-depth*
vars.doc:
The maximum depth of stack traces to print when an Exception
  is thrown during a test.  Defaults to nil, which means print the 
  complete stack trace.

vars.name: are
vars.doc:
Checks multiple assertions with a template expression.
  See clojure.contrib.template/do-template for an explanation of
  templates.

  Example: (are (= _1 _2)  
                2 (+ 1 1)
                4 (* 2 2))
  Expands to: 
           (do (is (= 2 (+ 1 1)))
               (is (= 4 (* 2 2))))

  Note: This breaks some reporting features, such as line numbers.

vars.name: assert-any
vars.doc:
Returns generic assertion code for any test, including macros, Java
  method calls, or isolated symbols.

vars.name: assert-predicate
vars.doc:
Returns generic assertion code for any functional predicate.  The
  'expected' argument to 'report' will contains the original form, the
  'actual' argument will contain the form with all its sub-forms
  evaluated.  If the predicate returns false, the 'actual' form will
  be wrapped in (not...).

vars.name: compose-fixtures
vars.doc:
Composes two fixture functions, creating a new fixture function
  that combines their behavior.

vars.name: deftest
vars.doc:
Defines a test function with no arguments.  Test functions may call
  other tests, so tests may be composed.  If you compose tests, you
  should also define a function named test-ns-hook; run-tests will
  call test-ns-hook instead of testing all vars.

  Note: Actually, the test body goes in the :test metadata on the var,
  and the real function (the value of the var) calls test-var on
  itself.

  When *load-tests* is false, deftest is ignored.

vars.name: deftest-
vars.doc: Like deftest but creates a private var.

vars.name: file-position
vars.doc:
Returns a vector [filename line-number] for the nth call up the
  stack.

vars.name: function?
vars.doc:
Returns true if argument is a function or a symbol that resolves to
  a function (not a macro).

vars.name: get-possibly-unbound-var
vars.doc: Like var-get but returns nil if the var is unbound.

vars.name: inc-report-counter
vars.doc:
Increments the named counter in *report-counters*, a ref to a map.
  Does nothing if *report-counters* is nil.

vars.name: is
vars.doc:
Generic assertion macro.  'form' is any predicate test.
  'msg' is an optional message to attach to the assertion.
  
  Example: (is (= 4 (+ 2 2)) "Two plus two should be 4")

  Special forms:

  (is (thrown? c body)) checks that an instance of c is thrown from
  body, fails if not; then returns the thing thrown.

  (is (thrown-with-msg? c re body)) checks that an instance of c is
  thrown AND that the message on the exception matches (with
  re-matches) the regular expression re.

vars.name: join-fixtures
vars.doc:
Composes a collection of fixtures, in order.  Always returns a valid
  fixture function, even if the collection is empty.

vars.name: report
vars.doc:
Generic reporting function, may be overridden to plug in
   different report formats (e.g., TAP, JUnit).  Assertions such as
   'is' call 'report' to indicate results.  The argument given to
   'report' will be a map with a :type key.  See the documentation at
   the top of test_is.clj for more information on the types of
   arguments for 'report'.

vars.name: run-all-tests
vars.doc:
Runs all tests in all namespaces; prints results.
  Optional argument is a regular expression; only namespaces with
  names matching the regular expression (with re-matches) will be
  tested.

vars.name: run-tests
vars.doc:
Runs all tests in the given namespaces; prints results.
  Defaults to current namespace if none given.

vars.name: set-test
vars.doc:
Experimental.
  Sets :test metadata of the named var to a fn with the given body.
  The var must already exist.  Does not modify the value of the var.

  When *load-tests* is false, set-test is ignored.

vars.name: test-all-vars
vars.doc: Calls test-var on every var interned in the namespace, with fixtures.

vars.name: test-ns
vars.doc:
If the namespace defines a function named test-ns-hook, calls that.
  Otherwise, calls test-all-vars on the namespace.  'ns' is a
  namespace object or a symbol.

  Internally binds *report-counters* to a ref initialized to
  *inital-report-counters*.  Returns the final, dereferenced state of
  *report-counters*.

vars.name: test-var
vars.doc:
If v has a function in its :test metadata, calls that function,
  with *testing-vars* bound to (conj *testing-vars* v).

vars.name: testing
vars.doc:
Adds a new string to the list of testing contexts.  May be nested,
  but must occur inside a test function (deftest).

vars.name: testing-contexts-str
vars.doc:
Returns a string representation of the current test context. Joins
  strings in *testing-contexts* with spaces.

vars.name: testing-vars-str
vars.doc:
Returns a string representation of the current test.  Renders names
  in *testing-vars* as a list, then the source file and line of
  current assertion.

vars.name: try-expr
vars.doc:
Used by the 'is' macro to catch unexpected exceptions.
  You don't call this.

vars.name: with-test
vars.doc:
Takes any definition form (that returns a Var) as the first argument.
  Remaining body goes in the :test metadata function for that Var.

  When *load-tests* is false, only evaluates the definition, ignoring
  the tests.

vars.name: with-test-out
vars.doc: Runs body with *out* bound to the value of *test-out*.

vars.name: print-tap-diagnostic
vars.doc:
Prints a TAP diagnostic line.  data is a (possibly multi-line)
  string.

vars.name: print-tap-fail
vars.doc: Prints a TAP 'not ok' line.  msg is a string, with no line breaks

vars.name: print-tap-pass
vars.doc: Prints a TAP 'ok' line.  msg is a string, with no line breaks

vars.name: print-tap-plan
vars.doc: Prints a TAP plan line like '1..n'.  n is the number of tests

vars.name: with-tap-output
vars.doc:
Execute body with modified test-is reporting functions that produce
  TAP output

vars.name: *trace-depth*
vars.doc: Current stack depth of traced function calls.

vars.name: deftrace
vars.doc:
Use in place of defn; traces each call/return of this fn, including
  arguments.  Nested calls to deftrace'd functions will print a
  tree-like structure.

vars.name: trace
vars.doc:
Sends name (optional) and value to the tracer function, then
  returns value.  May be wrapped around any expression without
  affecting the result.

vars.name: trace-fn-call
vars.doc:
Traces a single call to a function f with args.  'name' is the
  symbol name of the function.

vars.name: trace-indent
vars.doc: Returns an indentation string based on *trace-depth*

vars.name: tracer
vars.doc:
This function is called by trace.  Prints to standard output, but
  may be rebound to do anything you like.  'name' is optional.

vars.name: defadt
vars.doc:
Define an algebraic data type name by an exhaustive list of constructors.
   Each constructor can be a symbol (argument-free constructor) or a
   list consisting of a tag symbol followed by the argument symbols.
   The data type tag must be a keyword.

vars.name: deftype
vars.doc:
Define a data type by a type tag (a namespace-qualified keyword)
   and a symbol naming the constructor function. Optionally, a
   constructor and a deconstructor function can be given as well,
   the defaults being clojure.core/identity and clojure.core/list.
   The full constructor associated with constructor-name calls the
   constructor function and attaches the type tag to its result
   as metadata. The deconstructor function must return the arguments
   to be passed to the constructor in order to create an equivalent
   object. It is used for printing and matching.

vars.name: deftype-
vars.doc: Same as deftype but the constructor is private.

vars.name: match
vars.doc:
Given a value and a list of template-expr clauses, evaluate the first
   expr whose template matches the value. There are four kinds of templates:
   1) Lists of the form (tag x1 x2 ...) match instances of types
      whose constructor has the same form as the list.
   2) Quoted lists of the form '(x1 x2 ...) match lists of the same
      length.
   3) Vectors of the form [x1 x2 ...] match vectors of the same length.
   4) Maps of the form {:key1 x1 :key2 x2 ...} match maps that have
      the same keys as the template, but which can have additional keys
      that are not part of the template.
   The values x1, x2, ... can be symbols or non-symbol values. Non-symbols
   must be equal to the corresponding values in the object to be matched.
   Symbols will be bound to the corresponding value in the object in the
   evaluation of expr. If the same symbol occurs more than once in a,
   template the corresponding elements of the object must be equal
   for the template to match.

vars.name: multiset
vars.doc: Multiset (demo implementation)

vars.name: keywordize-keys
vars.doc: Recursively transforms all map keys from strings to keywords.

vars.name: macroexpand-all
vars.doc: Recursively performs all possible macroexpansions in form.

vars.name: postwalk
vars.doc:
Performs a depth-first, post-order traversal of form.  Calls f on
  each sub-form, uses f's return value in place of the original.
  Recognizes all Clojure data structures except sorted-map-by.
  Consumes seqs as with doall.

vars.name: postwalk-demo
vars.doc:
Demonstrates the behavior of postwalk by printing each form as it is
  walked.  Returns form.

vars.name: postwalk-replace
vars.doc:
Recursively transforms form by replacing keys in smap with their
  values.  Like clojure/replace but works on any data structure.  Does
  replacement at the leaves of the tree first.

vars.name: prewalk
vars.doc: Like postwalk, but does pre-order traversal.

vars.name: prewalk-demo
vars.doc:
Demonstrates the behavior of prewalk by printing each form as it is
  walked.  Returns form.

vars.name: prewalk-replace
vars.doc:
Recursively transforms form by replacing keys in smap with their
  values.  Like clojure/replace but works on any data structure.  Does
  replacement at the root of the tree first.

vars.name: stringify-keys
vars.doc: Recursively transforms all map keys from keywords to strings.

vars.name: walk
vars.doc:
Traverses form, an arbitrary data structure.  inner and outer are
  functions.  Applies inner to each element of form, building up a
  data structure of the same type, then applies outer to the result.
  Recognizes all Clojure data structures except sorted-map-by.
  Consumes seqs as with doall.

vars.name: with-ns
vars.doc:
Evaluates body in another namespace.  ns is either a namespace
  object or a symbol.  This makes it possible to define functions in
  namespaces other than the current one.

vars.name: with-temp-ns
vars.doc:
Evaluates body in an anonymous namespace, which is then immediately
  removed.  The temporary namespace will 'refer' clojure.core.

vars.name: ancestors
vars.doc:
Returns a lazy sequence of all ancestors of location loc, starting
  with loc and proceeding to loc's parent node and on through to the
  root of the tree.

vars.name: children
vars.doc:
Returns a lazy sequence of all immediate children of location loc,
  left-to-right.

vars.name: children-auto
vars.doc:
Returns a lazy sequence of all immediate children of location loc,
  left-to-right, marked so that a following tag= predicate will auto-descend.

vars.name: descendants
vars.doc:
Returns a lazy sequence of all descendants of location loc, in
  depth-first order, left-to-right, starting with loc.

vars.name: left-locs
vars.doc: Returns a lazy sequence of locations to the left of loc, starting with loc.

vars.name: leftmost?
vars.doc: Returns true if there are no more nodes to the left of location loc.

vars.name: right-locs
vars.doc: Returns a lazy sequence of locations to the right of loc, starting with loc.

vars.name: rightmost?
vars.doc: Returns true if there are no more nodes to the right of location loc.

vars.name: attr
vars.doc: Returns the xml attribute named attrname, of the xml node at location loc.

vars.name: attr=
vars.doc:
Returns a query predicate that matches a node when it has an
  attribute named attrname whose value is attrval.

vars.name: seq-test
vars.doc:
Returns a query predicate that matches a node when its xml content
  matches the query expresions given.

vars.name: tag=
vars.doc:
Returns a query predicate that matches a node when its is a tag
  named tagname.

vars.name: text
vars.doc:
Returns the textual contents of the given location, similar to
  xpaths's value-of

vars.name: text=
vars.doc:
Returns a query predicate that matches a node when its textual
  content equals s.

vars.name: xml->
vars.doc:
The loc is passed to the first predicate.  If the predicate returns
  a collection, each value of the collection is passed to the next
  predicate.  If it returns a location, the location is passed to the
  next predicate.  If it returns true, the input location is passed to
  the next predicate.  If it returns false or nil, the next predicate
  is not called.

  This process is repeated, passing the processed results of each
  predicate to the next predicate.  xml-> returns the final sequence.
  The entire chain is evaluated lazily.

  There are also special predicates: keywords are converted to tag=,
  strings to text=, and vectors to sub-queries that return true if
  they match.

  See the footer of zip-query.clj for examples.

vars.name: xml1->
vars.doc:
Returns the first item from loc based on the query predicates
  given.  See xml->
